Here is a summary of my activity on Root-Me :
Welcome to my cybersecurity journey. Here I share my experiences, insights, and adventures in the field.

After completing my Cybersecurity Bachelor's at Howest and a rewarding internship at Apside in Paris, I decided to pursue a Master’s degree in Data Science and Artificial Intelligence at the Data ScienceTech Institute (DSTI) in Paris.
Cybersecurity is becoming increasingly powered by data science and AI. From anomaly detection to automated threat response, modern security relies on advanced analytics and intelligent systems.
My studies at DSTI revolve around:
Machine Learning for Security– Building models for threat and anomaly detection
Data Analysis– Working with large-scale security datasets
AI Systems– Exploring both defensive applications and AI-related vulnerabilities
Big Data Technologies– Securing and managing massive infrastructures

This program helps me combine traditional cybersecurity expertise with cutting-edge data science. It’s a powerful mix—security provides context, and data science provides the tools to tackle modern threats at scale.

Apside Internship: My internship in Paris gave me hands-on experience in enterprise cybersecurity. Apside’s broad presence—spanning automotive, aeronautics, banking, telecom, and more—exposed me to a wide range of real-world challenges.
Cloud & Infra– Cloud security, containers, secure architecture
Cybersecurity Guide Development– A growing knowledge base of tools and techniques for students and professionals

l: 🛡️ Web Security Project in Skövde, Sweden
p: In Skövde, Sweden, I took part in an intensive project week organized by the University of Skövde's Network and Systems Administration group. Students from Howest and Skövde collaborated under the guidance of professionals like Joakim Kävrestad (Swedish police digital forensics expert) and Nico Declerck (senior network administrator).

We performed vulnerability assessments on intentionally outdated servers, which pushed us beyond modern exploits and into older technologies. The project took place in a live environment where teams had to attack and defend simultaneously.
No major vulnerabilities emerged, but the experience highlighted how basic oversights—like default passwords—can compromise entire systems.

While the hands-on aspect was excellent, the lack of structured reviews made it harder to track missed vulnerabilities. Including dedicated review sessions in future editions would greatly improve the learning experience.
During my internship in Paris, I discovered the INA reverse engineering challenge through Apside’s cybersecurity lead. It was an ideal opportunity to test and sharpen my technical capabilities.

I teamed up with another intern to tackle the challenge. Reverse engineering demands precision—understanding compiled code, uncovering logic, and identifying hidden behavior without access to the source code.
Gain proficiency with professional reverse engineering tools
Think like both an attacker and a developer
It reinforced that reverse engineering is as much about patience and methodical thinking as it is about technical skill.

I attended the 12th EU MITRE ATT&CK Community Workshop in Brussels, hosted by the Centre for Cybersecurity Belgium (CCB). The event gathered professionals and enthusiasts for a day of learning and knowledge-sharing.
MITRE ATT&CK is a globally recognized framework that documents real-world adversary tactics and techniques. It’s a crucial resource for detection, prevention, and incident response.

The workshop connected me with the European cybersecurity community and gave me practical insights into how ATT&CK is applied in real enterprise environments. Seeing how practitioners use the framework day-to-day was especially valuable.
From June 5–7, I participated in the IBM Quantum Challenge 2024, exploring quantum computing through IBM’s Qiskit framework.

Quantum computing represents both innovation and risk. It could revolutionize computation—but also threatens modern encryption. Understanding quantum fundamentals is essential for preparing future-proof security systems.
Executing code on actual IBM quantum processors

Working with Qiskit and real quantum hardware was eye-opening. While current quantum computers aren’t yet a threat to encryption, understanding the direction of the field is crucial. Staying ahead of emerging tech is far better than reacting later.
